meanings: to emphasize something or make something easier to notice
wordSentence: He likes to wear clothes that accentuate his muscular build.
let's accentuate the saxophones during this piece by having the sax players stand up

meanings:
based on or involving conjecture.
"the evidence was deemed too conjectural"
Similar:
speculative
suppositional
theoretical
hypothetical
putative
academic
wordSentence: a necessarily conjectural account of Shakespeare's life, since there is so little hard information

meanings: happy and friendly in atmosphere or character
wordSentence: the hiking club attracts a wide range of convivial people who share a love of the outdoors
The book condemns some of society's wealthiest members as decadent fools.
a wealthy and decadent lifestyle
a decadent hotel room, complete with a hot tub

meanings:
outstandingly bad; shocking.
"egregious abuses of copyright"
Similar:
shocking
appalling
horrific
horrifying
horrible
terrible
awful
egregious is sometimes confused with gregarious
wordSentence: … the public perception is that too many corporate executives have committed egregious breaches of trust by cooking the books, shading the truth, and enriching themselves with huge stock-option profits while shareholders suffered breathtaking losses.
History cannot be rewritten, but some of its more egregious errors can be corrected—at least in part, at least symbolically.  … Or so assume a growing number of human-rights advocates.
an egregious example of political bias
the student's theme was marred by a number of egregious errors in spelling

meanings:
LITERARY
soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.
"the evanescent Arctic summer"
Similar:
vanishing
fading
evaporating
melting away
disappearing

PHYSICS
denoting a field or wave which extends into a region where it cannot propagate and whose amplitude therefore decreases with distance.
wordSentence: beauty that is as evanescent as a rainbow

meanings: (used about a person) acting in a loud, confident way that attracts attention
bright and easily noticed
wordSentence: Crazy artists, or flamboyant ones, can be strangely comforting. We feel we understand where their visions come from; we're lulled by the symmetry of turbulent art and turbulent lives.
Equally flamboyant is the group's singer, Andy Bell, who prances around the stage dressed at various times like an astronaut, a space creature or a Mexican senorita.
… he was living in the flamboyant, urbane manner he craved, in an apartment that suited his Balzacian fantasies of success …
the flamboyant gestures of the conductor
has a gallery of flamboyant gestures that makes him easy to imitate

meanings: to take action to prevent somebody from doing something or something from happening
wordSentence: Negotiations failed to forestall the conflict.
His comments were meant to forestall criticism of his proposal.
He forestalled critics by offering a defense of the project.

meanings:
deny or contradict (a fact or statement).
"the impact of the railways cannot be gainsaid"
Similar:
deny
dispute
disagree with
argue with
dissent from
contradict

speak against or oppose (someone).
"none could gainsay her"
wordSentence: it can't be gainsaid that most people wish they had more time and money
repeatedly tried to gainsay me, though every point I made was backed up by facts

meanings: to cover iron or steel in a whitish metal (zinc) to protect it from being damaged by water (rusting)
wordSentence: The group is hoping to galvanize public opinion against the proposed law.
The website has galvanized support for the project.
a factory where steel is galvanized

meanings: done or acting without making sensible judgement or caring about the possible harmful effects
wordSentence: They participated in the indiscriminate slaughter of countless innocent victims.
He objects to the indiscriminate use of pesticides.
She has been indiscriminate in choosing her friends.

meanings: lasting for a very short time
wordSentence: He experienced a momentary loss of consciousness.
the pain of the flu shot was only momentary

meanings: ordinary; not interesting or exciting
wordSentence: On him, a mundane navy blazer looked like an Armani dinner jacket; around him, a dusky locker room became the chandeliered lobby of the Savoy.
How did our ancestors pass from the mundane activity of counting to the concept of 'number' in the abstract, devoid of any particular collection of objects to label?
They decided on buttock tattoos, rather than the more mundane engagement ring, because a tattoo is permanent. You can always pawn a ring.
The day began with the mundane business of getting my white chiffon dress shortened …

meanings:
causing annoyance or difficulty.
"nettlesome regional disputes"
wordSentence: a few nettlesome details that still required attention

meanings: to officially make an agreement, order, etc. lose its legal force
to make something have no effect, power or importance
wordSentence: The law has been nullified by the U.S. Supreme Court.
The penalty nullified the goal.

meanings: to remove a difficulty, problem or the need for something
wordSentence: The new medical treatment obviates the need for surgery.
The new treatment obviates many of the risks associated with surgery.

meanings: present everywhere at the same time
wordSentence: The problem is omnipresent and unavoidable.
seeking some much-needed relief from the omnipresent noise of the big city

meanings: to force somebody out of a job or position of power, especially in order to take his/her place
wordSentence: The rebels ousted the dictator from power.
Large national banks are ousting local banks in many communities.

meanings: that is easily felt by the senses or the mind
that can be handled or touched
wordSentence: A positive patch-test result, measured by a visible and palpable localized response, denotes a delayed hypersensitivity response …

There's a palpable feeling of community here: owner Lee McLemore stocks the store with a surprisingly large wine selection, police chief Andy Williams moonlights in the prepared-foods section and barbecues in the parking lot, and George Watkins personally fills the shelves with his superb tupelo honey.
When I'm back in nature after months of walking around on concrete and living in boxes, I feel a palpable internal shift.
I felt a palpable sense of relief.

meanings:
the state of being deceitful and untrustworthy.
"it was an example of his perfidy"
Similar:
treachery
duplicity
deceit
perfidiousness
deceitfulness
disloyalty
wordSentence: A man who built his entire administration upon demanding unctuous loyalty from his allies now finds himself wounded by their shabby betrayal. You'd have to go back to one of Spain's humpbacked Hapsburgs to find court perfidy of the variety that is currently depleting the president's power.

The petty Robespierres on the public stage appeal to "the real America" to rise up in fury against presidential perfidies; yet in poll after poll the real America keeps telling Washington that it has gone bonkers.
I lived there off and on for twenty years, through graduate studies, marriage, the end of marriage, the perfidies of middle age, all the while unaware of passion.
They are guilty of perfidy.
his wife's perfidy was a moment of uncharacteristic weakness

meanings: given or produced in great quantity
wordSentence: He offered profuse apologies for being late.
They were profuse in their thanks.

meanings: very eager to start an argument or fight; expressing an opinion very strongly
wordSentence: That's a bass for you: pugnacious, adaptable and ever ready to demonstrate that the first order of business on any given day, drought or no drought, is eating anything that it can fit its big, powerful mouth around.
Herz sees himself as a pugnacious sardine going up against rule-flouting sharks.
He was a short man with heavy shoulders, a slight potbelly, puffy blue eyes, and a pugnacious expression.
Podhoretz takes a more pugnacious and protesting stance, insisting on the word "seriousness" at all times and punctuating it with the word "moral".

meanings: having or showing good judgement and understanding
wordSentence: … the winner is praised for his sagacious grasp of the hopes and anxieties of the public, the loser is excoriated for the many and obvious blunders that derailed his candidacy …
It has allowed him to pre-empt conservative political attacks, to appear sagacious despite his inexperience …
With commendably sagacious foresight, I sneaked spoils as well to the elders of key Judean cities whose good will I was cultivating for the future …
It has been suggested that we go to sleep at night because it is then too dark to do anything else; but owls, who are a venerably sagacious folk, do not sleep in the night-time.
a sagacious critique of the current social climate in our nation

meanings: cheerful, hopeful and confident about the future
wordSentence: He has been strangely sanguine about this, blandly ignoring the mounting evidence that dissident elements in the police are stirring trouble …

How could a man of his caliber be this sanguine about a war we had barely begun to fight? He gave me the McNamara look, eyes focusing boldly through rimless glasses. "Every quantitative measurement we have shows that we're winning this war," he said.
Yet if there were sanguine expectations of war profits and unlimited booty from the Spanish empire, … those hopes were dramatically confounded …

meanings: not very much; not as much as necessary
wordSentence: Food was in scant supply.
She paid scant attention to the facts.
Police found scant evidence of fraud.
don't scant the peanut butter on those sandwiches!

meanings:
underhand, unscrupulous, or dishonest behaviour or activities.
"a firm that investigates commercial skulduggery"
Similar:
trickery
swindling
fraudulence
double-dealing
sharp practice
wordSentence: tales of espionage and skulduggery
the company's apparently healthy bottom line was merely an illusion, the result of years of accounting skulduggery

meanings: of little importance; not worth considering
wordSentence: His later memory, untutored and unsupported by anything so trivial as evidence or documents, now flourished and ran wild.
I had never heard anyone speak of their parents in this way; I never even knew you could make them seem trivial …
But the last tribute was to be a struggle among states for possession of the trivial remains of a man who in life had known as much revilement as honor.
statistics and other trivial matters

meanings: without any intelligence or interest
wordSentence: Waiting rooms, as I'm sure you know, are small rooms with plenty of chairs for waiting, as well as piles of old, dull magazines to read and some vapid paintings … while you endure the boredom that doctors and dentists inflict on their patients before bringing them in to poke them and prod them and do all the miserable things that such people are paid to do.
In a secular age, symbolic rituals such as lighting the Olympic torch inevitably risk seeming a little vapid.

… the incompetent servant, by whomsoever employed, is always against his employer. Even those born governors, noble and right honourable creatures, who have been the most imbecile in high places, have uniformly shown themselves the most opposed (sometimes in belying distrust, sometimes in vapid insolence) to THEIR employer. What is in such wise true of the public master and servant, is equally true of the private master and servant all the world over.
a song with vapid lyrics
